titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to his Papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Encoded by Deborah Anema and Laura Burt

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-04 05:13:54 -0500.

change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.abstract: Roger Wilkinson was an Indiana University professor of physics from 1946-1968. Collection consists of correspondence, publications, lecture notes, and laboratory reports. The lecture notes included in the collection are from both Wilkinson's tenure as a professor as well as notes he took as a student at the University of Chicago. The Publication series consists of reprints of articles authored or co-authored by Wilkinson, 1951-1968.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Three folders of student recommendations and 1 folder of Nobel recommendations are closed to researchers.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Roger Gilbert Wilkinson was born in Buffville, Kansas on September 6th, 1912, but spent much of his childhood in Buffalo, New York. After graduating from High School in Buffalo, he entered the University of Chicago where he received his B.S. in Physics in 1938 and his Ph.D. eight years later. While at Chicago, Wilkinson worked with Enrico Fermi's group helping to develop the first self-sustaining nuclear reactor and was present in Stagg Stadium when the reactor was first operated on December 12, 1942. From 1942 to 1944 he served as a junior physicist in the University's Metallurgical Laboratory. Wilkinson was also associated with the Manhattan project from 1943 to 1946 working with some of the world's best physicists at both the Oak Ridge and Los Alamos laboratories.

After the war Wilkinson returned to Chicago to finish his Ph.D. before coming to Indiana University as an Instructor in the fall of 1946. He was promoted to Assistant Professor the following year, Associate Professor in 1950, and then to full Professor in 1956. Throughout his time at Indiana Wilkinson taught all levels of physics, from freshmen introductory courses to the most advanced graduate courses. A member of Sigma Xi, the international honor society of research scientists and engineers, and a fellow of the American Physical Society, he published frequently and made significant contributions to the scholarly literature in his primary areas of research: nuclear physics, beta and gamma ray spectroscopy, and beta-gamma and gamma-gamma angular correlation studies.
Wilkinson retired from teaching in 1968 following the death of his wife Betty the previous year. He passed away on Christmas Day, 1969.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: Correspondence; Teaching course materials; Student course materials; and Publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Roger G. Wilkinson papers span 1921-1968 and are arranged in four series: Correspondence; Teaching course materials; Student course materials; and Publications. Series divisions and arrangement were taken almost directly from the collection's original order, and folder titles were retained in most cases.

Series one, Correspondence dates from 1921 to 1968 and is further organized into two sub-series, personal correspondence and professional correspondence, a distinction made by Wilkinson. During processing correspondents who appeared more than once within each sub-series were assigned their own folders. Both sub-series are arranged alphabetically by surname. Much of the professional correspondence relates to research findings in Wilkinson's areas of interest, particularly nuclear physics and beta and gamma ray spectroscopy. Three files of recommendation letters from Wilkinson for his doctoral students and one folder containing Wilkinson's recommendations for the 1962 Nobel Prize in Physics are restricted and can be found at the end of box 4.

Teaching materials is the second series and is arranged by course number and then chronologically by academic semester. The series consists primarily of handwritten class lecture notes for classes Wilkinson taught during his tenure at Indiana University, 1946- 1968. It also includes grade averages and summaries for many classes, tests, and test answer keys.

Series three is Student course materials. It spans Wilkinson's years as a student at the University of Chicago, 1937-1945, and is arranged chronologically by academic quarter. The series includes many notebooks containing Wilkinson's handwritten lecture notes and finished laboratory reports. No tests or homework are included in the series.

The last and smallest series is Publications, consisting of one folder of article reprints dating from 1951 to 1968. The articles are either solely or jointly authored by Wilkinson and come primarily from The Physics Review.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have not transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Roger G. Wilkinson papers, Collection C285, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.
